[SYNTAX]: A few overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "The very length and size of the fortifications proved to be a disadvantage.") slightly impede smooth reading.
[LEXICON]: Minor word-choice awkwardness (e.g., "size" instead of "extent" in fortifications description).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from discussing Petersburg’s defenses (Dimmock Line) to the battle events without explicit connection.
[STRUCTURE]: Dense, unbuffered transitions between paragraphs (e.g., jump from raids to June 15 battle events).
Abrupt, unrelated paragraph about Sir Joshua Reynolds disrupts narrative flow.

[LOGIC]: Sudden, unconnected description of 18th-century art studio breaks contextual coherence.

[SYNTAX]: Abrupt transition between sentences (e.g., "July 23" to "Four days later").
[LEXICON]: Inconsistent inclusion of unrelated quotes (e.g., "A big shingle...", TAGI text) disrupts flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden, unexplained insertion of unrelated quotes (TAGI, "big shingle") disrupts narrative logic.
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts (e.g., from explosion to "A big shingle..." without context).

[SYNTAX]: Some sentences are overly complex with multiple nested clauses (e.g., "Although this raised the morale of the Confederates, it did not change the course of the campaign.").
[TRANSITION]: Minor abrupt shifts between closely related war events (e.g., "Soon it was all over." after detailed battle descriptions).

[LOGIC]: Completely unrelated paragraphs (e.g., Boucher/Bahá'í Cause, romantic dialogue) disrupt thematic continuity.
[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt time jumps (e.g., August 20 to September events) without transitional phrases.
[CLARITY]: Contradictory tone shifts (military analysis vs. emotional dialogue).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally lengthy, complex sentence structures may slightly impede immediate clarity.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift to discussing "special artists" at the end without explicit connection to preceding narrative.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unrelated narrative shifts (e.g., "Mildred" scene, philosophical passage) disrupt flow.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., attack plan details).

[LOGIC]: Non-sequitur paragraphs (romantic and religious texts) contradict historical context.
[STRUCTURE]: Lack of transitional links between military events and inserted fragments.

[GRAMMAR]: Inconsistent verb tense in "which has pushed" (should be past tense for consistency)

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift to analyzing Five Forks’ significance without clear connector
[STRUCTURE]: Late introduction of Lt. Col. Horace Porter feels disconnected

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally formal or abrupt sentence structures (e.g., "The flight of the Confederate government was promptly begun").

[TRANSITION]: Minor jumps between immediate events (e.g., Petersburg fall) and broader strategic consequences (e.g., Lincoln’s visit, final surrender).
